Our Facility and Regulated Substances



The Stillwater Water Treatment Plant is a municipally owned 18 million gallon water treatment facility which produces a clean and bacteriologically safe potable water meeting federal and state requirements. One of the chemicals used in the disinfection process is Chlorine.  



The water treatment plant purchases chlorine in one (1) ton steel cylinders and are kept in an enclosed building with a ventilation system that is connected to a Chlorine Scrubber System.  This Scrubber system is automatically engaged when chlorine gas is detected in the room.  The maximum quantity stored at the water treatment facility is 12,000 pounds.



Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies and Chemical specific Prevention Steps



The Stillwater Water Treatment Plant is dedicated to the safety of their employees and to the citizens living in the area.  The water plant utilizes employee training, written policies, maintenance procedures, technology, and emergency backup systems to achieve a safe working environment and to limit the potential of a chlorine gas release to the atmosphere. 

 

Training:  

All new employees work with an experienced plant operator to achieve on the job training.



Annually, all employees, must receive 4 hours renewal training as per Oklahoma Department of Environmental Quality rules and regulations for license recertification.



All Stillwater employees attend quarterly safety training under PEOSH regulations.

All water plant employees attend monthly safety meetings.



Chlorine System Policy



Two operators will always be present when working on chlorine cylinders or in the chlorine room.

The exhaust fan will be turned on before operator enters the chlorine building.

One of the two operators will remain outside of the chlorine room and observe the other operator while he is in the room.

When changing leads from one cylinder to another cylinder, a new lead washer will always be used.

Operators will

immediately notify the Supervisor of any changes, in or around the chlorine building.



Only authorized employees are allowed in the chlorine building.

In the case of a chlorine release, evacuate the area, then call the Fire Department and call your supervisor.



Maintenance Procedures



 Daily:

Check all flexible connectors for damage or deterioration, if any is evident, replace immediately.

Inspect all isolated valves and replace if any deterioration is evident.

Inspect chlorine booster pumps.

Visually inspect all piping, both gas and water, for any signs of damage.

Check both chlorinator and chlorine storage rooms to assure they are clean and orderly.



Weekly:

Inspect all vents and fans to insure they are operating correctly.

Inspect lighting for proper operation.

Check SCBA tanks for proper pressure.  Check facemasks and air hoses for nicks or cracks.



Monthly:

Hoist system

Check hoist and travel limit device.  If any problem is found correct it immediately.

Inspect cables and lifting bar.  If excessive wear or damage is found, replace immediately.

Inspect trolley wheels, fasteners, track wheel stud nuts and suspension bolts.

Check cables and leads for broken wires, loose or corroded terminals, and damaged insulation.

Check wheels for bearing wear, as indicated by excessive looseness of wheel on stud.  Also check track for wear.



Annualy the entire hoist system is inspected and certifed by Gaffy Crane.



Chlorine Scales:



Inspect for wear each time chlorine cylinders are replaced.

Re-set tare weights to 4000 lbs. after replacing new cylinders.

Check for frayed wire insulation and loose connections.



Chlorine Detectors: (Tank storage room and chlorinator feeder room)

Check chlorine detectors control module for proper operation

Mix a week solution of sodium hypochlorite in squeeze bottle.  Place next to gas sensor and puff vapor toward sensor.  Check chlorine alarm system for; local alarm notification, SCADA alarm notification and

auto start of chlorine gas scrubber system.



Check Chlorine Scrubber System to ensure unit pump and blower are running normal.  Check to ensure that all louvers in the Chlorine storage room activate.

Reset Scrubber System and return to automatic controls.

Report any abnormalities immediately to Plant Supervisor and/or Plant Superintendent.



Annually:

Thoroughly inspect flexible connectors(whips) and replace any discolored or damaged connectors.

Thoroughly inspect manifold isolation valves and replace any discolored or damaged valves.

Replace exhaust fans drive belt and lubricate motor

Rebuild chlorine ejectors as per manufacturers instructions

Regulators with flow indicator should be inspected and rebuilt as per manufacturers recommendations.

Rotometers should be disassembled and cleaned on an annual basis and replace all O-rings.

Chlorinators should be disassembled and inspected annually and the Loss of

Vacuum/High Vacuum Switch needs to be rebuilt as per manufactures recommendations.



Technology

Computers:  

SCADA system for operations and monitoring the water treatment plant.



Chlorine Gas Scrubber System:  

The City of Stillwater water treatment plant installed a scrubber system to the chlorine storage facility.  This unit is fully automatic and will energize when chlorine gas is detected.  This unit is capable of treating up to 4,700 lbs of chlorine with a maximum outlet concentration of 5 mg/L.



Security:

The City of Stillwater water treatment plant keeps all plant building doors locked and have installed alarms on all exterior doors.  Security cameras have been installed throughout the plant for added perimeter security.  These cameras are monitored by the water plant staff and can be monitored by the Stillwater Emergency Coordination and Communications Center.



Emergency Backup Systems:

The City of Stillwater installed a 2,000,000 watt diesel backup generator at the treatment facility.  This unit is fully automatic and will energi

ze 15 seconds after a loss of power.  This unit is maintained and monitored by Stillwater Power.



The water treatment facility has a trailer mounted 180KVA generator that is used to power individual buildings/chemical systems and remote pumping stations.



All major systems and/or components have redundant backup motors, chemical feeders, electrical feeds, etc., and can be operated by the computer SCADA system, local operator interface stations and can be manually energized at the unit.



Five Year Accident History:

The Stillwater Water Treatment Facility did not have any accidental release of chlorine in the past five years



Emergency Response Program:

The staff at the water treatment plant are not first responders.  All chemical release emergencies will be handled by the Stillwater Fire Department (hazmat).  Chemical releases and other emergency procedures are outlined in the Operations Handbook.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety:

The Stillwater Water Treatment plant is currently requiring all chemical suppliers to conduct annual chemical safety meetings for all of water plant employees.
